I went for lunch a couple of Mondays ago, eager to try their pierogies that I've heard so much about. I went around 1pm, and it was packed (huge line), but they took orders quickly. I ordered potato pancakes, haluski, and potato and cheddar pierogies....only to be told that they ran out of potato and cheddar and only had farmer's cheese or mushroom pierogies. Not being a fan of those flavors, I passed on the pierogies altogether, which was hugely disappointing. The annoying thing was that they had a ton of potato and cheddar pierogies for sale in their frozen case that I could plainly see. I was tempted just to buy some and ask them to cook them up for me. I mean, I don't know why they couldn't just take some of the ones they have for sale and use those, but I guess they had their reasons. So right off of the bat, I was super disappointed...I would think that a place specializing in pieorgies should not run out of one of their most basic flavors so early into their lunch service.

So just potato pancakes and haluski it was. I placed my order, got a number, and sat down to wait. I'm not an impatient person, and I understand that restaurants get busy during lunch time. But it took over 30 mins to get my food. Over 30 mins...for a few potato pancakes and some haluski! I don't know if this is typical or not, but at a deli-style takeout place, I was hoping to get my food a little sooner.

Anyway, the food finally came, and I couldn't wait to dig in. Sadly, it was not worth the wait. The potato pancakes were borderline burnt on the bottom, which gave them an unpleasant charred taste. Worse than that, I felt like I basically received a plate of oil with a side of potato pancake. Seriously, these things were swimming in grease....when I would press down on a pancake to cut it, the oil from within the pancake bubbled up to the surface. I understand the pancakes are fried, so obviously a little oil is expected, but these things tasted like nothing but burnt grease. I ate one and it immediately sat in my stomach like a lead balloon, so I had to trash the other two. The haluski was a little better, but nothing notable...no better or worse than haluski I've had elsewhere.

So overall from the lack of cheddar pierogies, to the long wait for food, to the grease-laden bombs that are their potato pancakes, I have to say that I was not too impressed by S&D. That being said, because of their stellar reputation and my love of pierogies, I do plan to go back and hopefully catch them on a day when they have the cheddar flavor in stock to see if I have a better experience. I'll update this review once I'm able to get my paws on some pierogies!

Although I have no Polish heritage, I have enjoyed Polish cuisine over the years. The perogis and stuffed cabbage were excellent. The kielbasa was tasty and cooked to perfection. It's crowded so you might have to get a meal to take away.
The mushroom pierogi are delicious. I wasn't a fan of the cheddar. I'd come back.

Stopped here as part of the Pittsburgh Food tour and for my taste (& money) the pierogis at Forgotten Taste in Moon Township are much better! 

I tried two variations  - cheese and farmhouse and definitely preferred the cheese, as I found the farmhouse to be a bit too tart. I found the texture of the pierogis to be less firm here, hence my not liking them as much.

So I also got to try Hunter's Stew as one person in our foodie tour had a mild milk intolerance and this was basically sausage with sauerkraut- I liked the taste of this and wouldn't mind getting it if return here.

Btw, it was a bit disappointing too, that no-one of Polish origin seemed to be working the shop the day we came - I was all ready to try out the few words of Polish I had picked up while living/ working in Warsaw and when I greeted the staff behind the counter with a hearty  "Dzie? dobry" was met with blank looks and they said they didn't speak any Polish!

Yelp Review 65/2017

We wanted some pierogies, and that's precisely what we got.  And they were delicious.

The service was quick and friendly, and the food was exactly as described, just like you're hoping it'll be.  I recommend getting on down there and getting yourself some if you're on the fence about it.

One word: Polish style haluszki. A large pile of egg noodles mixed with a little cooked cabbage... And then, thick chunks of bacon and farmer cheese piled on top. Sounds kinda boring doesn't it? Trust me, this is some of the most outstanding comfort food I have ever consumed. If this is boring, I am now ok with boring. If this is what life is like in Poland, I'm ready to pack up and go... Well at least back to the Polish Deli anyway. If there was one food I had to eat for the rest of my life...it probably wouldn't be Polish style haluszki, but it would be on the top of my list for sure! 

Ok enough of that. So a plate of haluszki and four meat pierogis is more than enough food for lunch. Go to the S&D Polish Deli and get yours now!

Trying this place for the first time. Being part Polish, I grew up with homemade Polish food. These pierogis are not bad. Well cooked, but these are the smallest pierogis I've ever had. For $6 I would rather go to Pierogis Plus in McKees Rocks & pick up a dozen fat pierogis.

I could have sworn for a couple minutes I was in Gliwice or Krakow, Poland while standing in S&D Polish Deli in the Strip District of downtown Pittsburgh. From the jarred and pickled root vegetables like beets and apples to one of Poland's most popular soups, Zurek, a sour rye soup often served in bread bowls (chunked potatoes and sausage). I was there for the pierogies, the fresh ready-to-eat options were potato and cheddar cheese, potato and farmer's cheese and potato and mushroom. $5 for 4 pierogies. You can order them in or to go - they have maybe 6 - 8 tables but it was a tight fit with the bustling holiday crowd ordering sausages, baked goods and such.

I highly recommend strolling to the back of the store to stock up on their frozen soups: borscht (beet/dumpling soup), mushroom and Zurek. They also have a large freezer filled with at least 10 different types of pierogies to purchase and serve at home. For my next visit, I'll have to try something new like one of the noodle dishes served with sausage and beets. It's all about the beets. I was a wink away from purchasing the Pope John Paul shirt on the wall (fun fact: PPJ was born in Krakow, Poland - I have the earrings, now all I need is the shirt to complete the outfit). This place is as close to Poland as it gets - thank you fellow yelpers for leading me in the right direction;) Or shall I say, Dzi?kuj??
The dumplings are just SO good!  I love old school places like this.  Didn't have the sausages, but they looked heavenly.  If you're in Pittsburgh, this is a MUST-stop on the strip.

OMGG SO DELICIOUS!!!!!

It can't get any fulfilling than this.  I mean, it's just out of this world good.  Table full of women behind me were moaning after the meal too.  It's absolutely ridiculous, how yummy it is.

Ordered kielbasy platter $11 (comes w/ 1 kielbasy, noodles, 4 pierogies)
Stuffed cabbage $3 (1 piece)
Potato pancakes $5 (3 in a order)
And a pickle

Holy moly, their pickle is to die for.  It's SO good, I could've probably ate 6 more.

Pierogies were so good, we ordered 10 more and stuffed ourselves silly.  The kraut/mushroom pierogies were my fav, it has a tang that makes you go Mmmmm.... The potato cheese one is so good too Jesus Christ...  They'll mix em up, just try them all, they're amazing.  So good!!! Ughhhhh!!!!

If I lived in Pittsburgh, I would want to live here.  Please go.  The women are so friendly and nice.  Omg, I ate so much here!!!  Made my day!!!!

If you like pierogis, I highly recommend checking out the S&D polish deli in the Strip District. They have some different flavor choices (i.e. Cheese, potato, etc) and other homemade traditional polish food (i.e.: pigs in a blanket) which can be ordered for eating in, takeout or even purchased to cook at home. Food can be ordered and paid for and then brought out when it is ready. 

We were here on a weekend and while it was busy, we were able to get a table. The interior is like a small store/market with a small area with some tables to eat. Service was friendly and pretty quick too. Think in between fast food service and sit down meal. Restroom was available with a key for customers. Prices also very reasonable. 

I will definitely be back to get some delicious pierogis from S&D again!

Awesome. Tried a bunch of stuff. Haluski, potato pancakes and pierogies were fantastic. Stuffed cabbage and kielbasa were good. Cheap. Really is a deli with a few tables. Go. Best restaurant I have been to in Pittsburgh.

I might need more than two hands to calculate how many times I've visited Pittsburgh, yet it has completely slipped my mind to have Pierogi. Yes, shame on me. 

There is no city with a greater Polish influence than Pittsburgh, and there is no Polish dish more famous than the Pierogi. The yelp faithful clearly feel S&D is king, so to S&D I go. 

Located in the strip district, there's nothing fancy about this market, just classics dishes that feel like they came out of your adopted polish grandmothers kitchen. 

Aside from the pierogis, i sampled other old world favorites like stuffed cabbage and potato pancakes. It's clear with one bite that these are all homemade from scratch. The pierogis pretty much melt in your mouth, tender and flavorful. 

S&D is the real deal. With prices like these, you are only limited by your stomach. Culinary bucket list check off....

First meal in Pittsburgh was courtesy of S&D!  Casual dining area inside of a Polish deli/grocery store.

Servings are quite large and totally shareable, especially stuff like the Pierogi Platter, Potato Pancakes.  Best to bring a friend in tow, get a coupla things to share!

Out of the 3 different kinds of pierogis on the platter (krautmush, cheddar/potato, & farmer's cheese), my fav was the cheddar/potato.  Dumplings themselves were quite large and obviously handmade.  

Potato Pancakes were quite large, thick, and primarily crunchy.  So again, they were quite heavy, definitely more than 1 serving.  

Works out to be ~$1/pierogi, so best value again is to share.
Very good original Polish deli.  It is nice to find something authentic and good.  Thank you.

Another 5 star review of S&D.  How about that.

I have to start this off by saying the first time I had S&D's pierogi was at the History Center's Hometown Homegrown event in which they judged about a dozen pierogi from around the city.  S&D's potato and farm cheese were my favorite (sorry, Grandma Urbanik!).  They are incredible.  Like, someone's little Polish grandma is making these.  Literally.  S&D won, by the way.

So this place is 3/4 store selling some serious Polish imports from candy and bakery items to the cheese and prepared foods counter.  If you are looking for anything Eastern European, this is one of the places to start.  Hell, even if you're looking for your lamb butter mold for Easter, get it here. 
The other 1/4 is restaurant counter service.  They have platters and big plates to share, but I usually get my own plate of not fried pierogi.  The farm cheese is always the "special" of the day when I'm there somehow so it ends up being painfully cheap too.  Like I said, these are so great.  The potato pancakes are also done perfectly.  Being picky, I can't say much for the haluski or kielbasy ("you don't know what's good!", responds everyone in my family).

They also sell gift boxes of sweets and/or sausages as well as Polish gift/heritage items.  Lanters, Matrioszka dolls, t shirts, you know.  So if babcia needs a birthday gift, get down to the end of the strip.  You must, must, must have these pierogi while you're around.

It was crowded. It was no frills. We had to wait for a table and swoop on in as soon as two people stood up to leave. But oh boy, was it delicious. 

I ordered the Polish Platter ($11.00) which included 3 pierogi, haluszki, and stuffed cabbage. The haluszki was delightful. Pierogi were better than my great grandmas (don't tell Buba) and the stuffed cabbage was almost as good (Buba makes the best stuffed cabbage in the history of the world).

Everything was swimming in butter and that made me very happy.

I would rate this deli more than FIVE stars if I could! The food is Fantastic and the service is quick and friendly. Lots of options but the pierogis are a Must! Very authentic, tastes just like our last trip to Poland :)
We tried a couple pastry options on our last visit and were very happy with our selections. 
This is one of our "Go To" places anytime we visit Pittsburgh. We will be back

Wow!  Simply wow, this place is amazing. If you like Polish food you need to go here for lunch. The Polish platter was delicious, it was just like grandma's home cooking.  The pierogies were cooked to perfection in butter and onions;  the haluszki was fantastic, the noodles were nice and buttery and the cabbage had just a little crunch, and the cabbage roll was moist and full of flavor. Also tried the smoked kielbasa with kraut and potato pancakes, both were great too.  A must stop for lunch while in the strip district.

Driving through Pittsburgh and stopped in. Okay for the price and what you get. Very greasy potato pancakes and doughy pierogi.  Wouldn't go back unless this poppyseed roll I have is good. Keep you posted.

They were out of cabbage rolls when we arrived at 1 pm.  Next time we'll have to get there earlier!  I ordered the meatless platter and my husband had the kielbasa platter.  The pirogies were wonderful!  The cabbage and noodles were average - bland and swimming in butter.  I grew up on this food and was slightly disappointed with the potato pancakes(greasy)and kielbasa (way over cooked nearly burnt).  I would  like to give it another try to see if it was just a fluke.  We did get one piece of kielbasa from the deli and it was very good.  Went with high expectations and left a little disappointed.

The deli has a wide selection of polish meats, mustards, frozen perogies, and canned goods such as pickles and turnips. They also have a service counter that cooks polish specialties such as kielbasa and perogies.

Yeah, they have great peirogies, and halushki, and desserts, and meats, and the taste appeals to picky eaters and food snobs alike and no one ever suspects this to be such a great place and everyone is so nice and everything else that everyone talks about that contributes to a solid run-on-sentence about one of the most visited and reviewed places in the Strip District or probably Pittsburgh in general.

I'll keep taking my friends here when they come to visit, but what really keeps me coming back is the Cracovia Super Extra Hot Mustard. It's an import and it's sincerely the greatest mustard I've ever had. Serve it with some latkes; mix it with honey and sugar for a good chicken nugget dipping sauce; put a spoonful into a roux for a spicy edge to your mac and cheese; spread it on some bread for your cold cuts; or, let's be honest, just eat a little bit with a spoon every time you see it in the fridge.

Buy some Cracovia Super Extra Hot Mustard, and treat yourself to some good Polish lunch while you're at it. If you don't like the mustard, let me know, and I can name a few dozen people who would be glad to take it off your hands. Nawet drwala powala!
My first time here and it was good. I don't remember the items I ordered or pronounce them. If you never tried polish food then you start trying it here.

In Pittsburgh and what do you eat? Polish food!!! On our drive in I convinced boyfriend to stop at this deli for an authentic polish lunch..all I really wanted were pierogis!

We found street parking easily and made our way in. There was a huge line at the deli counter..we took a quick glance and could see why! Tons of smoked meats and polish delights!

Walk back a little further and there are single and communal tables for dining and a very small window to place your order. We stared at the menu for a long time before deciding on the polish platter. This included pierogis, stuffed cabbage and haluski. He also ordered red borsht which I was pretty excited to try! You pay at the window and they hand you a number..find a seat and wait.

The only reason I'm not giving five stars is because of the extreme smoke coming from the kitchen and the cold temps inside..

They finally called out our number to grab our tray of food. The pierogis were absolutely perfect..buttery and warm..sautéed just right. The stuffed cabbage was in a deliciously sweet tomato sauce which kind of melded with the butter from the haluski..so delicious. 

Pretty sure I won't have to do much convincing to get him to go back tomorrow too!

If you want a warm, heart meal...go here! You will never leave hungry from this restaurant. I was very happy by the humble look of everything and the extremely friendly staff. The table are family style, so you really feel good eating here. I wish I took some frozen perogies back with me, but they would never be as good as getting them fresh made from here!

3.5 stars. Don't hate me pleaseeee.

Atmosphere: deli in the front, food and seating in the back. Extra casual. Came in a Saturday at noon and it was crowded but people come in and out and it wasn't too hard to snag a table. 

Food: All aboard the train to carbstown and starchville. Not complaining about that fact, these foods are true polish staples, just stated as a note to come prepared hungry and leave knowing you'll have a lot of carbs in the belly :) kielbasy platter and an order of potato pancakes for two people. Everything is reasonably priced, especially for the portions. The kielbasa was good, but on the drier side. The pierogis were tasty, however I asked if they could do one cheddar and potato and two potato and farmers cheese since the partner doesn't like mushrooms. The hostess wrote it down on the receipt, but unfortunately the cooks gave us one potato and cheddar cheese and TWO sauerkraut and mushroom. I realize I could've said something, but I had already shoved half of the pierogis in my mouth lol. Either way, they're good and filling and there is strong flavors of cheddar cheese and the tang of sauerkraut in each respective pierogi. What takes the cake here is the haluszki. It's light, flavorful, and has a bit of a pepper kick to it. I could seriously come back to just eat a whole plate of this. The noodles were perfectly cooked too, not too mushy or not too hard. 

Potato pancakes were a little too oily, but they were crunchy and tasted like what you would expect. 

Also stopped by the deli to get a lemon-filled polish doughnut, which was airy and filled with lots of lemon jelly-like filling. 

Service: very friendly people work here. It's comforting. The guy at the deli let us try some of the Moscow ham for free and it was delicious.
When you're making pierogies, this is the place for flour and fillings. Using the right dough is life changing! Great customer service. Will return time and time again.

Came here on a Saturday while they had a street grill going. I ordered the kielbasa sandwich. 

The kielbasa is nicely executed. It's smoky, crisp-skinned, and carries a complex eastern european flavor profile. The horseradish/beet red relish was very nice on this sandwich.

However, the sandwich is very imbalanced. There is too much bread. There was too much sauerkraut. The meat was not allowed to shine in the sandwich.

Traveled from Houston on my way to Erie I had heard about this place and really wanted to try it. The hours state that they're open til 4:30 and says they serve lunch til "3:30ish."  We get there at 3:07pm and are told that lunch ends at 3pm.  Well if lunch ends at 3pm why not put that on yelp?  Or your website?  Was really looking forward to some kielbasa and pierogies but I had to settle for the pizza place around the corner. Sad

Delightful lunch surprise - I yelped something while my friend had taken me to the Strip District during my visit. 

It was a bit of a bargain, too. My friend and I split the pierogi platter, some stuffed cabbage rolls, and potato pancakes. 

The sour cream was a little sweet, which I thought was odd. But all three varieties of pierogi were delicious. The cabbage rolls were tender and tasty, and the potato pancakes were a little oily, but also good. 

Would definitely go again during another visit.

Living 15 min from Alexandra Foods in Chicago, my go to place for pierogi, I was pleasantly surprised that their pierogi made it to Pittsburgh. Bit overpriced for my taste 4 pierogi for $6, but otherwise great selection of deli meats and cheeses and other Polish items including Polish themed t-shirts.
Easily the best pierogi I've ever eaten. Wife feels the same way. This is seriously amazing food. Have lunch. Good price. Great selection of meats and polish candies.

We stopped in here yesterday after dining at Penn Avenue Fish Company and found a most delectable Polish cheesecake. Peppered with coconut, it almost reminded me of a tiramisu with its subtle sweetness and silky texture. I even got a free Polish lollipop! Kay walked out with some Polish sausages that filled the car with an intoxicating, carnivorous aroma. S&D is an ethnic gem in a part of town overflowing with them.

Great quality polish food, old school joint, and inexpensive prices. This is a place I wish I could have brought my grandmother. 

S&D is a solid joint busting your favorite polish dishes. Cabbage, sausages, pirogies, they got it all. We got here close to the end of their business day. After stuffing our faces with a couple of sandwiches, my friend wasn't sure if we could eat here. I let him know it wouldn't be a problem for me. 

Everything was delicious and I left more than satisfied. This seems like a wonderful option for a cheap lunch in Pittsburgh.

Oh my goodness!! The best pierogies I've had in a long time. The deli is at the front half along with a lot of Polish snacks and foods. In the back half is a window where you order and a sit down area. It isn't fancy but my goodness the pierogies are out of this world! I got the farmers cheese and the mushroom and sauerkraut types. I fried the cheese and got the mushroom and kraut pierogies boiled. I preferred the fried version. You can also take frozen or fresh pierogies home for later if you'd like. Definitely a great find!

Coming from Detroit, we knew we had to try Pittsburgh's Polish food scene. Every website recommended this place and it did not disappoint! Very good food (first time I ever tried haluszki!) and grocery! Casual, economical, homemade.

I don't really see the big deal. Pittsburgh should not claim to be a city that has Polish-forward cuisine if this place is meant to be representative. I like my pierogies with a bit more chew (such as the ones I had when I visited Szczecin, Poland). The ones here have too high a ratio of wrapper to filling and they were over cooked to the point where they became soggy. 

I also found the fillings slightly off-putting. They tend to stuff their pierogies with sautéed veggies and cheese, which is absolutely fine, but their fillings were also too wet so the pierogies only had one texture upon consumption: mushy. 

In terms of cleanliness, perhaps I made the mistake of eating here, but I felt very uncomfortable by how old the pastries in the display cabinet appeared and by the abundance of crumbs on the ground. 

If they can figure out how to properly cook pierogies, I may consider coming back

Named best pierogies in Pittsburgh and I support it. Delicious pierogies well worth the wait. I got the pierogi platter. Came with 4 krautmush, 4 chedder, 4 farmers cheese. All cooked well and tasted great! You may eat in or take out, I got take out because I needed to catch my bus. This was my last meal in Pittsburgh. Will definitely need to stop by again to try the other things on their menu.

My coworkers all swear by this place so I had to eventually check it out. I'm not familiar with Polish cuisine so this was an eye opener. The store itself is like a deli/corner grocery store rather than a restaurant. There were only 2 tables for seating so either the lines are super long or you have to get them perogies to go! 

It's cash-only which is a no-no in my book. The dishes behind the glass counter didn't look or smell all that appealing to me. I split a beef perogie meal with my hubby and the taste was okay, not bad. They are like European dumplings, so if you have never had a real dumpling before, then I guess this is fine but I'm a dumpling/bao zi/dim sum connoisseur so perogies just pale in comparison. The wrapper is kind of hard and thick and the filling is very bland. I did, however, very much enjoy the onion butter black pepper sauce on top. That was lip-smackingly good. The haluski pasta side was also buttery, smooth and delicious. 

Kind of expensive for the small amount of food you get. Good for a little snack but does not quite do it for me for an entree.

Visiting from Orlando,  FL. Yum! This gem is a small deli/ grocery store. They cook them to order so be prepared to wait a little bit. Ordered the Kielbasy Platter. It came with one kielbasa, 3 pierogies and some pasta. 

The pierogies and kielbasa were delicious but the pasta was a little bit dry. 

It is an inexpensive little place and the food is tasty. I would come back!

Came here because I heard they had the best pierogis in town. These pierogis did not disappoint. We got 1 order of the cheddar cheese ones that include 4 pierogis. Tasted like a Mac n cheese potato dumpling! What more could you ask for. Seating can be limited depending what time you go but seats open up at you wait for your food. They offer the pierogis to be fired for an extra $1 but we got the cooked ones and they come in like a cheesy milky buttery sauce. Not sure exactly what the sauce is but it's delicious with the pierogis. If you're in the area I would definitely recommend these as a snack!

Great authentic Polish deli. Stuffed cabbage was delicious! The prices are reasonable - $3 per stuffed cabbage, $6 for stew, and $5 for the cabbage, kielbasa and mushroom dish. All were very good, but the cabbage was the best. I got my order to go. They also have Polish clothing and souvenirs, groceries, candies, and deli items. The home made pickles are also very good. They have a freezer in the back with frozen dishes as well. I will definitely be going back.
Amazing pierogis and potato pancakes! I ordered the mixed and matched pierogis - cheddar, farm cheese and Kraut & mushroom! This place is a must to stop by while you are in the district!

The perogies are were its at! I'm biased but I'd skip the rest of the menu (not much of an eastern european food fan tbh) and just eat the perogies. 

They have three regular perogie flavors and have a daily special flavor on rotation. The three regular flavors are cheddar potato, farmers cheese and potato, and kraut and mushrooms. My favorite were the kraut ones because they funny enough, remind me of chinese dumplings and I am a big mushroom fan. 

I could have done without the keilbasa sausage I got. It was pretty hard and dry when I got it and I mainly ordered it for the kraut, which was unremarkable (made with pork but rather two-dimensional.)

I'm not a qualified pierogi expert, but I liked our orders of the potato and farmers cheese (4 for $5) as well as the sweet cheese (4 for $4). I think these are what authentic (i.e, not vegan or hipsterized) pirogies are supposed to be like. They were simple and hit the spot for a quick morning snack. S&D Deli is a good place to start if you're attempting a food crawl of Pittsburgh with visitors.

Great food. We will definitely be back.  We had only pierogis and all were amazing.  particularly, I loved the kraut and meet combination and the farmers cheese by itself.  Next time, I will get both of those and maybe some kraut by itself, as that must be good as well.  Although the insides play a big part, the dough of the pierogis were exceptional and you could tell that they were very fresh and homemade.  Thank you.  

Note, that most of the other stores in the neighborhood are very touristy.  That's just an FYI.

I came for the pierogies, and I was not let down. This was my second stop for food in the strip district. We had already had a good sized meal next door, so we just shared a plate. I prefer mine cooked, rather than fried. They have several different flavors to choose from, and they are sort of swimming in this really nice butter sauce. They were very well done and great comfort food. I have no complaints, it is very stripped down and to the point. I enjoyed very much and would go back again and again

I am originally from Chicago and this is by far the best Polish deli I have been to since I left Chicago.  We ate lunch here and had the red Borsht, pierogi platter and Kielbasi platter and I feel like I am back home. The food is amazing and prices are really great!

This is one of the best places in Pittsburgh if you like East European food. I have been to Poland and this deli makes authentic delicious food.  Anything you order is good, but I prefer the cheese pierogies and sauerkraut pierogies. The halushkj is also great.  Take home some Wawel chocolate for dessert!

Some of you know my real last name. It is Polish and difficult for Americans to pronounce. Some of you also know that I lived in Central Europe for two years.  Thus, I have thankfully experienced authentic Polish cuisine.  Walking into S&D reminds me of being back in Kraków! Pleasant staff chatting in Polish, magazines with extraneous amounts of the letter "z.", and the smell of delicious pierogi!

I always pick up a few candy bars and other Polish food items, but I usually go there for lunch. My favorite items are the (authentic) halusky with farmer's cheese, and the kraut/mushroom pierogi. 

After I'm finished, I also grab some frozen pierogi from the freezer and order some sausage from the deli. The staff is always helpful.

So why the docked star? First of all, sometimes service in the lunch area is painfully slow.  Also, mostly on weekends, often half the lunch menu is unavailable by noon! I realize this is because S&D is popular and they use fresh ingredients. But I love my brunch halusky and am disappointed when it isn't available. 

Overall, however, I adore this place and stop in every time I am in the Strip District.
Oh My God!  Best pierogies ever! So glad I found this place. Next time I'm in Pittsburgh I will stock up to bring home!

I'm not Polish, but I might be after eating here. I've had countless of things on their menu. I can never come out for lunch around noon, so around 2-3pm I may stumble in here for a few pierogies. I have had their traditional cheese and potato , and today I had their kraut and mushroom. Always good. I tried for the first time, their Bigos. I love any form of vegetable and they had cabbage a d few other vegetables in here. It was on the salty side, but still edible. place is always nicely laid out. I love their selection of chocolates.  I had this little piece of chocolate called tiramisu. I forgot the name. but it's bite size. Perfect after a little lunch. Will come back here when I can. Love the inventive pierogies.

Authentic Polish food! Priced well! Nalesniki was delicious! Highly recommend it! It was a nice reunion for me and my old friends from Duff's. They were in town and wanted a taste of Pittsburgh so this place was perfect. It would be helpful to have more restrooms. The combination of mayo and sour cream, was not our favorite.The Polish style haluszki was awesome!
Gimme those sweet beets any day. I love the women who work there, too. Very helpful and accommodating.
